description:
This is one of my favorite objects in the Southern Hemisphere. Although it is quite faint, patient processing brings out some scary details. What do we have here? An underwater monster rising up to snatch the unsuspecting galaxy?

Cometary globules werenâ€™t recognized until 1976, when they were detected by the UK Schmidt Telescope in Australia. Although the head  of CG4 is opaque, it glows with light from nearby very hot stars. The red color probably comes from excited hydrogen.

There are two theories about how the unique shape of cometary globules developed. One theory holds that they were originally spherical nebula that were disrupted by a nearby supernova explosion. The other theory is that were shaped by stellar winds and radiation from hot, massive stars.

Tech Notes for ASA 500/3.6:
ASA Newtonian, 500 mm aperture, 1900mm focal length, F3.6
FLI Proline 16803, 9 mm pixel, 4096 X 4096
ASA DDM85 equatorial mount
Processing with PixInsight and Affinity Photo
title: Help! The Cometary Globule CG4
